Dear Sheffield City Council,
I am seeking information on policy and procedure implemented by the council referred to in  Steve Eccleston's email on 18 February 2020 10:16; Subject: trees: possible issue regarding email header "legal privilege applies etc"
The email states:
"I asked for potentially privileged emails involving
lawyers to carry this header right at the start of the process."
The requestor is seeking information that show how Steve Eccleston's and the legal office at the council communicated this workflow process to the team.
1.A Can the council confirm if this request by Steve Eccleston was reflected in any document retention policy or retention schedules? If so please provide the document.
1.B Please produce all correspondence, memoranda, documents, reports, records, statements,
notes, examinations, opinions, forms, electronic mail, and other documents and things that informed/communicated to officers the process of marking "potentially privileged emails" with a header related to "not subject to foi" or 'legal privilege applies etc'. at the start of the process referred to by Mr Eccleston.
Yours faithfully,
Marcus Combie

Dear Mr Combie
Thank you for your request of 27 December 2020 relating to the
communication of a records retention policy by Steve Eccleston, which we
received on 29/12/2020. We apologise for the significant delay in
responding to this request. This has been due to a substantial backlog of
requests due to the pandemic.
1.A Can the council confirm if this request by Steve Eccleston was
reflected in any document retention policy or retention schedules? If so
please provide the document.
Your reference is to an email of 18 February 2020, which we released to
you on 13 May 2022 (our ref: Response – Internal Review – Reference – FOI
/ 2019-20-1881 / IC-98355-J1F7). We have attached it for reference.
A document retention policy or retention schedule would contain what
information is held by the council and set out retention periods and final
disposition actions.[1][1] The council has a retention schedule and a
records management policy. Neither references the use of the header “not
subject to FOI” in emails or documents.
The retention or disposal of the emails with the header is not subject to
a retention policy of its own. Information is retained dependent on its
content, subject to business need or legal or best practice requirements.
The email of 18 February 2020 explains why emails were identified in this
way to provide a flag for appraisal should a request under information
rights legislation be received.
1.B Please produce all correspondence, memoranda, documents, reports,
records, statements, notes, examinations, opinions, forms, electronic
mail, and other documents and things that informed/communicated to
officers the process of marking "potentially privileged emails" with a
header related to "not subject to foi" or 'legal privilege applies etc'.
at the start of the process referred to by Mr Eccleston.
We would like to distinguish between two sets of markings, ‘legal
privilege applies, etc’ on the one hand; and “not subject to FOI” on the
other hand.
The first marking is normal and essential to any communication by council
lawyers with council services. Whether that is in the subject heading or
in their email signatures, it is standard practice for a lawyer to protect
their client’s confidentiality by reference to the legal professional
privilege protection provided under section 42 of the Freedom of
Information Act 2000 (FOI); Regulation 12(5)(b) of the Environmental
Information Regulations 2004 (EIR) and section 19 of Schedule 2 (Part 4)
of the Data Protection Act 2018 (DPA).
However, privilege “belongs” to the client not the lawyers so genuinely
privileged material can be released. In our situation, the council is the
client, and privileged discussions between lawyers and clients are a safe
space to consider ambiguous issues confidentially. Under FOI and EIR,
there must be a “public interest” in retaining privilege on top of the
privilege itself, to avoid disclosure. The courts have set a high
threshold for privileged material to be disclosed. In Murray-Smith v
Information Commissioner ([2]EA/2021/0039V, 4 August 2021) the First Tier
Tribunal (FTT) said: “A public authority will most often be entitled to
obtain legal advice on an issue and to rely on LPP to withhold it even
when a request is made under FOIA,  because of the in-built public
interest established by the courts in maintaining LPP” (paragraph 35).
The other marking of emails has been “not subject to FOI”. No official
record of Sheffield City Council is “not subject to FOI”. We understand
our statutory obligation under section 1 of the FOIA. Information may be
withheld under an exemption, but that is under the Act itself. It is never
“Not subject to FOI”. Unfortunately, there was an elision between “legal
privilege” and “not subject to FOI”, which is not supported by the
legislation. We sincerely regret the use of this phrase for the
misunderstanding that it has caused.
The decision to mark emails “not subject to FOI” was not part of a policy
process. It was a response to contentious litigation. Council officers
anticipated large numbers of FOI requests. They wanted to make sure that
privileged material was properly identified and flagged for checking
against the tests before disclosure. There was a risk that this might not
happen if emails were not clearly identified, given the volume of
correspondence. The header text was designed to do that. But that flag did
not in itself determine disclosure or non-disclosure. Each bundle of
records had to be reviewed on a case-by-case basis to determine if there
were exemptions, and then, subject them to the public interest test.
The reference to the “start of the process” could be deemed to be 2013,
which is the year agreed between the council’s cabinet and street tree
campaigners to provide documentation for the Street Trees Archive. There
will be emails with the header “not subject to FOI” as part of that
disclosure (unless, separate and apart from that marking, they can be
withheld under FOI, EIR, or DPA).
But to the best of our knowledge, we hold no record “from the start of the
process” which sets out how officers were informed or communicated with
regarding the flagging of emails that may contain exempt information if
requested by the public.
We understand that the identification of emails which may be legally
privileged, in anticipation of FOI/EIR requests, was raised verbally
between the council lawyer and the director with responsibility for the
Highways Service at the time the council legal team received instructions
to consider injunction proceedings relating to protests against street
tree felling.
We do not have information to add to that.
We have responded to more than 450 requests for information about street
trees under FOI and EIR in the past seven years. We understand the public
interest in the process of response, as much as the responses themselves.
Where information has not been sourced by us in response to your request,
we hope that the Bevan Brittan report into the use of the label “not
subject to FOI”; the publication of the Street Tree Archive and Sir Mark
Lowcock’s Street Trees Inquiry will provide further avenues for the
scrutiny of our efforts.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [3]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[4]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Kind Regards,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ
